Also, there's a huge car park, so moving in and out is hassle free.

body:
This is the website which will be used to manage the RCSA room ballot.

If you're a current student not already logged on I recommend you start by logging in so you can view allocations for all rooms.  These will then be updated in real time during room ballots etc.  To log in, simply click the link at the top left of the browser window.

Once logged in, you can use the check box at the top to choose between viewing the current allocations (to find out what room your friend's in or remember the name of the guy who lives next door) and next years allocations (to help you choose a room during that stressful balloting period)

You can use the gold bar to navigate between the staircases and houses and the light yellow bar to see more detailed information about a specific room.

To view all the rooms and their availability select Home from the first menu then Projector from the second menu

You can edit the descriptions of rooms and staircases and I encourage you to add lots of helpful information/reviews.  It would especially be great to see people adding photos for their rooms.  Make sure you click save when you're done or you will lose all your work.

The editing is done using markdown syntax which is fairly simple (just look at other rooms for examples).
name: Home

Q staircase is on High Court.

Q staircase has a lift, which is very useful for moving in and out each term (and getting to brunch when it's raining!). There are also two guest rooms and the IT office is based on the first floor. It was refurbished in Summer 2013.

body:
**The room:** The room is pretty damn huge for a Standard, and is a mirror-image of room 21. It has a sloping ceiling (very low at one side, and very high at the other). Most of the usual things are here -- notice board, desk, bed, chair, coffee table, desk lamp, built-in wardrobe with draws, bed-side table, bookcase. In addition, there is a sink and a big lamp, but there isn't a kettle (nor is there in any room in the house). With two lockable cupboards, there is plenty of holiday storage space. There are 4 pairs of plug sockets dotted around the room, but you'll still need an extension lead if you have lots of chargers or things like that.

**The window:** One of the walls of the room is a window. Quite a tall pane of the window opens, but not very wide, so the room can get hot when it's sunny -- the window is South-facing so you get sun from dawn 'till dusk. There are blinds rather than curtains because of the weird shape of the window, so sometimes you can get woken up early by daylight in the summer. You can't fully draw them either, instead you can only swivel them. Cons aside, the window's pretty good most of the time, and it's very nice having a light room (particularly compared to the other top floor rooms except 21, which have one tiny window and are quite gloomy).

**The floor:** The rooms on the top floor of the house are bigger than the ones on other floors, as they fit three rooms into each side of the house rather than five. There are two bathrooms (one on each side) and a kitchen at the end. The kitchen is a bit smaller than the floors below and has a crazy ceiling which you won't appreciate if you're any taller than about 5'8", but it contains a separate fridge and freezer, as well as a proper oven with real hobs. There's lots of storage in the kitchen and a table with chairs too. It's ideal if you like cooking. The baths/showers are temperamental: if you go in on a bad day then the tap will sputter and no water will come out of the shower. On a good day, it's fine... whatever, you get used to it.

**The house:** The house is located behind 1 Sylvester and 6 Adam's, and is about 2-3 minutes' walk away from the plodge. It's nice walking through the gardens to go places, but make sure you have an umbrella for those rainy days. Soundproofing isn't great, so if you want to sleep and someone's having a party, you should just join the party because you don't have a hope in hell of sleeping. In fact, the house is ideal for parties, especially if you're friends with the people who live around you. The house doesn't have Wi-Fi, and won't for the foreseeable future, so make sure you have an Ethernet cable. A nice thing about the house is that the rooms are fairly uniform, so you won't get lumbered with a horrible room whilst your neighbour lives in a luxurious pad.

**The locality:** Being 'far' from college is made easier by the laundry room in the 4 Adam's outhouse and the bike shed just opposite the front door. The laundry room is fit for purpose, but the college machines are faster, bigger and overall more effective, so making the trek across the gardens can sometimes be worth it. The house has two gardens, one of which is shared with 1 Sylvester and the other of which is behind 5 Adam's garden. The driveway of 1 Sylvester is very convenient for moving in and out if you arrive by car.

I've been pretty comprehensive (three cheers for procrastination!), but if you want to ask any questions, email me (cn319). I can't arrange for you to look round since I don't live here any more, so your best bet if you want to see it is to buzz the room and hope somebody nice lives there.

Clive (inhabitant of room 24, 2010-11)
name: Room 24

body:
This room is on the same floor as one of the kitchens, and two toilets (these are quite small, but both of them have sinks in the same room). The bathroom is large on this floor is large. This room is south facing - so good if you like lots of sunlight (not so good if you don't like being hot in the summer). This is probably one of the smallest standard rooms owned by the college. It's in a different section of the house to the bathroom, toilets, and kitchen, so these usually aren't heard in this room. 


_________________________________

It's not huge, and the internet box is in an awkward place, but if you arrange the furniture and decorate it nicely then it's very cosy and never cold. The furniture is not the same as in college (smaller wardrobe, chest of drawers, different coffee table, set of bookshelves rather than shelves on wall) but it's not awful. You get a really big windowsill too. Room 7 next door is like 3 times the size so make friends. Noone bothers you by using the loo/going to the kitchen because they're on the other side of the hallway. The house overall is a bit grotty but perfectly inhabitable.

body:
* Not garden facing, but since it's right on the end of the college it looks out onto the gardens just outside the front of college - better than bricks!
* Below kitchen, so not too much noise
* Light: really good light all day... may get annoying in the Summer (i'll let you know!)
* Storage space: unlike A16 there is NONE.
* The bedder (if she sticks to the same stair case) is amazzing - an absolute life saver.
* Kitchen: nice and big with two fridges

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

16/10/2012: Don't know who wrote all of that, but anyway, I'm Tom (trp31) and I'm living in A17 in 2012/2013. Here's everything I can think of to add to that:

* Light: the sun does get in your eyes in the afternoon. Slightly annoying, but you can draw one curtain as necessary.
* View: I think A16's view of the College gardens is nicer, but it's not terrible - some big trees right outside the window and you can look down onto Herschel Court.
* Balcony - is shared with B15. Also, nice set of French doors leading out onto it.
* Kitchen - That guy was lucky, two fridges?! There's only one fridge this year - only two kitchens between 21 people on the staircase means that the fridges do get packed. Also, I'm told that most of the fridges around have a freezer compartment, which was news to me as ours doesn't. Plenty of cupboard space though.
* Wi-Fi: My iPhone picks up the wireless network just fine, but my laptop can only connect about half of the time. It might just be my laptop though, there are routers throughout the staircase broadcasting the signal so I don't think it's an issue of distance from the centre of College. Which brings us to...
* Location: It IS a 60-second walk from A staircase to the bar, canteen or anything interesting in College. I'd prefer to live on S than A (or B to F, for that matter!) It's pretty annoying when you realise you haven't brought your card for the JCR and have to trek all the way back over to A :)
name: A17

body: The room's south-facing, so it gets quite a lot of light. It also backs onto the 1st floor walkway on Herschel Court, so people do walk past the window every now and again - which is a bit odd but you get used to it. Oh, also, the window opens right up so it can be like a back door if you need to let anyone in from outside. The room's right next to the stairs, 2 floors up from the bottom kitchen. There's not as much storage space as some other rooms, but there is an overhead locker for holiday storage, and there is plenty of floor space.
name: F7

body:
Not in the most fashionable part of College, but still a deccent room. There's good wireless access, good enough for the iPlayer and whatever else you may use the internet for. There have been a few problems with the bathroom over the year, but that'll hopefully be fixed by the time you'd move in. I've found it impossible to fully shut the window/door onto the balcony, but that seems pretty universal. I was able to fit all my clothes easily into the cupboard, though there wasn't a space to leave things locked up over holidays. The bed can be really easily moved into the corner, which I thought made the room feel a lot more homely...

Its conviently near the Plodge and the Library, but like the rest of block, there are no stairs to the ground floor, so you have to commute up J or H. Annoying when its raining, but you get used to it, like all of life's miseries. You'll make great use of the curtains, as you're at eye level with the computer room, but on the plus side, you get a great view of the flag on the two or three days a year that its flying (and of that one guy that goes to the computer room every night between 02.00 and 02.13), and the warming stare of the UL gives you a constant feeling of authoritarian cosiness.

On the whole, a good starter home for a young family on the move, or a fresher getting used to University.

---

Disagree with this pessimistic view of such a solid college room. Yeah I hate stairs and it's not fun trekking up to the 3rd floor but it's a cracking central spot above front court which gets 2 hours of solid sun for some sun bathing in the summer.

Also shares a balcony with J9(tbc?) whose occupant i was greatly indebted to after patching me up following a little tumble through the window onto the balcony. That is also greatly useful for keeping cold beers out on over the winter months...

So my opinion is that it will almost inevitably be a fresher room, but in the case that it turns out to be occupied by a veteran member of college, just chill out. There are better rooms out there, but there are also defitnitely worse rooms out there too....

---

Watch it you young whippersnapper, I fought a war for you lot!
name: I12

name: J8 (Function Room)

body:
There is no description for this room, why not consider adding one?
I was in there for my first undergraduate year (the 2012-13 academic year). I do not know what the college's refurbishment plans are, but in the future it is quite possible that this description will become redundant.
This is a Standard room however for some bizarre reason the bathroom is shared between 3 people. This was surprisingly never an inconvenience (apart from the morning of matriculation). 
Apart from this, the bathroom is ok; it contains a shower in which the water temperature output is suitable and the pressure is reasonable. 
The toilet has a powerful flush. Yet it does stink a little thus it can be annoying if the other two decides to leave the toilet door open.
The room size is not bad, but it *feels* smaller than other standard rooms and the desk is not that big. But this wasnt too bad since I like my libraries. If you are a fresher, check out https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3hjzNNvaELA and our library is open 24/7.
I like the kitchen, especially the new microwave which suddenly appeared during the year.
The best thing about this room is definitely the view of the Garden. That is one amazing view in my opinion, especially in the summer. You will have a balcony! Though the sun never shines on that side apart from in the Easter term when the days are longer.
The stairs are not too bad to ascend even if pissed. I am quite unfit and small yet after a few days I was still able to get used to the stairs.
Oh and there is no storage for the holidays.

Overall, this room is not too bad and served me well as a fresher. If you are a fresher; what room you get really doesnt matter, as long as it does the job, which this one does. I hope you have a good year!!

Mike :)
name: F20

body:
An L shaped room and a fairly good size, especially if you rearrange the furniture. No sink, but there is a lockable cupboard over the wardrobe. On the same floor as the kitchen, which is useful. Quite a few stairs. Convenient since its on front court. No wifi. A bit dark- not much daylight, a nice view of the garden though. Shares a balcony with a room on H, it can get a bit cold by the door and windows.

I lived here in 2010-11 - I broadly agree with all that has been said. That stain on the floor isn't sick, my friend dropped something on it. Sorry. There's now intermittent, very weak wifi that is useless for pretty much every purpose. The wardrobe seems to be smaller than some other rooms' as well.
name: G8

body:
Really nice room. Straight up one flight of stairs opposite plodge. Ensuite, with amazing shower. Great wardrobe space (3 doors), and tons of holiday storage in the locker above. Garden-facing, although can't actually see them when at desk because the balcony kind of blocks it. Opens on to the large shared walkway at the back of the college. Good daylight, although can get a little dark in the afternoons due to balcony above. I can't access eduroam wifi, although previous occupants have been able to and the internet plug is right next to the desk. Radiator is behind the desk which is annoying for the rest of the room. Kitchen is right next door which is convenient.

Overall really nice, conveniently located room!

(Rob - rab205)
name: J2

body:
One of the L-shaped rooms sharing a balcony with a room on S. The L-shape means the desk area gets a lot of light as it has 2 windows to the side and a balcony door behind it, but there is a nice corner for the bed with very little daylight which is excellent if you want to sleep during the day. The shape also means you have lots of wall space for storing things against. The walls are painted lilac and the carpet is beige / blue.

Even though this is a Standard room it is actually an almost-ensuite. The toilet and bathroom are shared with an office which is only occassionally used, and never for living in, so you can basically treat them as your own. The office is used for supervisions one or two evenings every couple of weeks, but also for start/end of term DoS meetings and admissions interviews so be aware you might get woken up if trying to have a lie-in at the start or end of term. Important to note all this is subject to change if a different Fellow takes over the room, or if the current Fellow uses it differently next year.

Storage: One of the smaller fitted wardrobes (i.e. 2 doors rather than 3) with a lockable cupboard above. Just as well there's a lockable cupboard... as it's on High Court plus two flights of stairs without a lift, moving in can be hard work.

All in all a very nice room which must be one of the best value rooms in the college building.
name: R11

body:
SIZE
----
Its a pretty standard room when it comes to size. When you come in you have the Bathroom right in front and the rest of the room to your right. There is a little section in between the two where the wardrobe is.
It narrows down in the corner where the desk is but not much.

LAYOUT
------
Desk is on the far corner of the room, by the window which is nice, you get lots of natural light and breeze. The bed is on the opposite corner, parallel to the window. 
The window is facing Long Court, which isnt as good as having a Garden View yes, but at least you dont get disturbed or waken up by that anoying 8am trolly like the people on the first floor. OH and you can see the top of the University Library tower and, guess what, BRICKS! Yeah, lots of them, that is basically your view.

BATHROOM
--------
Bathroom has a standard layout except for one very annoying thing...The mirror is far from the sink and on a different wall, its just stupid and is probably the only anoying thing about this room.
Shower pressure is ok, seen better, seen MUCH worse. Toilet works fine, no problems whatsoever.

STORAGE
-------
This is kind of an issue. The Wardrobe is relatively small (2 doors) and so is the overhead storage, if you are like me and have literally tons of stuff to store over the holidays, you will be struggling...
The room does leave lots of space for other stuff like for example, I have a large bean bag and 2 trunks which I use to keep my clothes and Sport gear and the room still looks big! You can fit 20 people in here for a proper room party!

Other
-----
What else can I say about this room... 
Dont worry about the noise, you might think since you are right above the bar that it will be noisy, but not at all, at least on the second floor. The radiator works well, perhaps too well. There are lots of sockets all over the place and the internet socket is right where you need it to be.

Overall this is a good room in a great staircase, if you dont mind not having a garden view and just want a nice, quiet, well located, functional standard plus, this is the room for you! Oh! and if you dont mind the University Library tower looking into your soul and using the sink and the mirror separately.

Miguel Barros Brito (mb753)
name: P8

body: Big room with lots of light (overlooks back and side garden/road). Bathroom next door (although there's no shower) and there's a cupboard in the little hallway which is handy to put stuff in over the holidays. Sylvester 1 in general is a really nice house to live in - feels more like a home than student accommodation! It's also got a good kitchen with 2 hobs/ovens, 3 fridges and a big freezer.
name: Room 6

body:
dark shoebox of a room, in a basement, with a very dark little windowless lifeless yellow bathroom that will make you feel/look like Edward norton in fight club when he hasn't slept for two months. Despite this, the actual room is cosy and always warm, but you will probably have to endure the sometimes lovely and sometimes absolutely infuriating experience of living underneath music students. They have pianos, and they will use them. Also the wardrobe is teeny tiny and so incredibly dark (worlds weakest light above it) that you probs won't be able to see what colour socks you're taking out, but at least it has some storage above it.

The problem with this room is that, though it looks out into the garden, it's less of a sweeping green view and more of a 'shrouded by bushes' kind of thing- it's in the darkest, most foresty corner of the garden. It is literally never light. It will be forever untouched by the gentle kiss of the sun. Buy some extra lamps. 

It's also next to the kitchen, which is great because you don't have to carry dirty dishes great distances to get to a big sink, but on the other hand this means the kitchen is as gloomy as everything else, with no window and one fridge the size of a tiny suitcase to share between eight. If you're a reptile or the kind of person that needs sun and nice atmosphere to feel at home, you probably won't like this room, but it has its charms.
name: B1

A nice bright room at the top centre of college (J is a good staircase in that it's opposite the plodge and library) with beautiful views of the garden. You share a bathroom between all 3 of you and a balcony with J15 but try and make friends with whoever is in J13 (claim to fame: Nick Clegg's old room) because they have a massive roof terrace. 
There are a lot of stairs (top floor) which is a pain on moving in/out days but otherwise it keeps you fit. The kitchen is on the same floor which is handy. 
You're right next to the bathroom (the toilet is separate from the shower and sink) but unfortunately the shower pressure is rubbish (unless they fix that over the summer). 
There is no overhead storage in this room, so either make friends with someone who has it or use the trunk room. The wardrobe is a good size though. Wifi connection is pretty good.
Overall it's a really lovely room!
name: J14

body:
This room is directly above the front door of the house, with a large set of windows overlooking the driveway, road and Trinity sports fields.

It is a good sized room for a Value, with everything you'd expect from a college room. It also includes a sink in the corner.

There is one large kitchen in the house, which can get easily cramped. There's ample cupboard space, but limited fridge space. The dining room houses a large freezer (again, limited space when ~12 people are trying to use it) and a table that can probably take a maximum of 8 people around it.

There is a toilet directly next to this room, which is great considering it is only really convenient for 2 other rooms - almost feels ensuite!
There is one shower, one bath/shower and one bath in the house and 4 further toilets.

You can also keep some of your things in the bedder's cupboard over the holidays if you're very nice to her :)

Summary
-------

Pros:

 - Large for a value room.
 - Nice view from window, and lets a lot of light in.
 - rarely used toilet right next door.
 - Good kitchen and dining area if you can find space for your perishables.
 - Nice bedder with a room to keep some things in over the holidays.
 - Sink in room.
 - Power showers, makes a big change from top floor rooms in Main College.

Cons:

 - Smaller than standard rooms in Main College, don't expect to host parties.
 - Not sure how much people who're walking on the road can see inside, especially troublesome coming in from a shower...
 - For 12 people, the kitchen and dining areas are small (only 4 hobs and one oven).
 - Ethernet port is under the bed, on the opposite side of the room from the desk. This requires you to use the WiFi (which has appeared this year) or have a large cable.
 - Only 2 showers between 12, hasn't caused issues after a term and a half but that may be due to very few of us getting up for 9am lectures...

Bryn Pickering (bp325) 11/02/2013
name: Room 8

body: A good size for a college standard room. With lockable storage above the wardrobe, a small balcony shared with the next room along on 'D' staircase and a decent shared bathroom. Plenty of light from the garden.
name: C17

body:
Overall, a really nice room - here's why:

 - It is one of the biggest rooms in college, which easily  makes up for a the lack of a balcony. 

 - It has an en-suite bathroom, with an added bonus of a heated towel rail, which some of the slightly older en-suites don't have. 

 - The desk is in a nice position, nearish the window and below the large notice board. Oh and in front of the radiator, so you can toast your toes while you work!

 - The wi-fi signal is brilliant, with a router just opposite the door. However the ethernet port is not that close to the desk, so bring a long cable if you haven't got wi-fi.

 - The room has some lovely views of the gardens, but is lucky enough not to be in the direct firing line of the sun. However the room is plenty bright enough.

 - The location is also good because it's one of the furthest rooms away from the Bop room - so if you're not a wild party animal you can still get some shut eye.

 - Also, despite the fact that this is classed a ground floor room, the slope of the ground outside means that only a giraffe would be able to stand outside and peep through your windows...

 - It's also nice and handy for the kitchen, which is just across the corridor.

 - Finally it's also worth mentioning that the lockable holiday storage above the wardrobe is reasonably large, although the wardrobe itself might be slightly small if you've got lots of coats etc. You also won't need to bring your own coat hangers, as the wardrobe already has some hotel-style ones built-in.
name: D2

body: Balcony not shared, just on the end overlooking the garden. Room slightly more spacious than many standards, because of being on the end of the building. There's a door to the fire escape staircase, but this is lockable. Doesn't get much light, though.
name: A15

body:
Large room on ground floor, probably most convenient room from porter's lodge. Next door to the games room, so you sometimes get odd noises, such as the chinese orchestra rehearsing, or tap dancing persistently banging through your wall.

**Has good quality piano.**

Main disadvantage (or advantage, whatever you want), is that it's ground floor facing onto college, so you get a fair number of passers by making noise, and spying into your room and whatnot. It's not that big of a worry though.
name: F6

body:
Typical first year room and with a bit of re-arrangement quite spacious. Great location just over bar and cafe and 2 seconds from restaurant.

Effort and knuckle destroying getting your stuff up and down 3 lots of tight stairs 3 times a year.

Bath and shower are dreadful. Shower temp oscillates from Good to scolding to freezing= not pleasant in the mornings. Bath is the alternative but is designed for a Hobit and sandpaper on the bottom of the bath isn't kind on the back.

No holiday storage which is frustrating.

For a first year room its perfect since s'all about the location and comforts of a nice bath are rarely considered.

Jack (jhc56)
name: M12

body:
Normal sized rectangular college room, looks out onto the second level walkway. Only issue is the wardrobe (and overhead space) is smaller than most. K staircase has a lift which is great for moving in and out (although you can now hear it saying 'doors opening'from the room since they 'fixed' the volume on it). There are also only 3 rooms on the floor and 10 in total on the staircase making it fairly quiet.

Close to the cafe/bar/canteen and porters lodge. You can hear the choir/music from the chapel occasionally too. 

Wifi signal is poor.
name: K6

body:
Nice room, a good size. Garden facing, with balcony, but not many people walk past so you are not disturbed often. The room gets reasonably good light, despite the large tree outside the window. 
Has overhead locker for holiday storage, with a large wardrobe.
name: B5

body:
Just a regular sized room, really.

Pretty sweet view, the fellows do supervisions and stuff across the hall, but aren't here at night so feel free to have gatherings. Good room.
name: F16

body: Nice big room, refurbished over Summer 2012. Two large windows and two balconies (one is a fire exit). Decent bathroom with a shelf, heated towel rack etc. Not a great amount of natural light due to some big trees outside the windows. Slightly awkward layout, in that you can either have the bed sticking out into the middle of the room, or next to the radiator and under the shelves. Good wireless reception as with most rooms in College now. Large wardrobe along with a fair amount of storage.
name: A8

body:
H12 is a lovely, spacious room which gets a lot of sunlight. There is also wifi across the whole room. Unfortunately, there is no holiday storage and it can be quite noisy, with noise travelling very well from front court. However, the sound of people’s drunken conversations echoing into your room can prove rather humorous, occasionally. You can also hear the delightful tunes of the choir on the odd evening and the room looks directly across front court into the geography fellow’s office, what more could you want? 

Lana (ljw62)
name: H12

body:
G staircase is on Front Court. It has several communal facilities on it which might make it a noisier place to live:

* Garden level - theatre workshop
* Court level - games room, payphone
* First floor - teaching rooms A and B, public toilet
name: Staircase G

body:
I staircase is on Front Court, above the Auditorium. It does not have a ground floor entrance, so to get to it you have to go up J staircase (with its unusually narrow door), and go across.

I staircase top kitchen has a lockable cupboard for each room, but most of the keys have disappeared, so they cannot be locked.
The kitchen is however in a reasonable condition apart from that.

The room is pretty much the same as most standard plus rooms. Opens onto the second floor walkway overlooking the plodge. Pretty handy in terms of its position in college but be aware noise carries into the courtyard from it, not one to take if you plan on being particularly loud.
name: Staircase I

body:
**Pros**

Its big, joint biggest room (as far as I know) in the grad house.

A few of chairs have been 'acquired' and will be left here for next year (housekeeping dependant).

Your own personal sink and little mirror with vanity light in the corner. Perfect for a rough night, morning, mid afternoon...

Kitchen with proper oven, hob, microwave, (small) fridge and freezer.

Its located in the scenic gardens.

**Cons**

The scenic gardens are about 5 minutes away from food.

If you know your neighbours noise shouldn't be an issue but the soundproofing is far from ideal.

The light is pretty poor, one small window in the corner is it for natural light. You get a desk light and a lamp however.

Slanty ceiling means the height of the room varies from about 4m to 1m and **will** result in at least one head injury during your stay here. With the kitchen ceilings verging on lethal.
name: Room 23

body:
Nice room, pretty standard size/shape. South facing windows (onto college) so it will probably get pretty hot in summer, but if you open the balcony door it gets to a nice temperature pretty quickly. You also get lots and lots of sun. Doesn't get cold at all, I've barely needed to use my radiator so far this year. The sun does shine across where the desk is for most of the day, which can be quite annoying.

There's a balcony shared with someone on D staircase. It's round the far side of college from all the amenities (bar, canteen, jcr etc), but that's not a big deal. It is three flights of stairs up, so that can be interesting when arriving/leaving. But you get lots of exercise. Kitchen on the floor above, plenty of lockable cupboards but rather small fridge (standard size in college, but they're pretty small).

No lockable storage compartment in the room, and the wardrobe is raised up 1-2 feel off the ground so it's a little difficult to reach the top shelves.

I would suggest bringing a extension cable as there's only one plug just by the desk, although there are several round the room. The ethernet port is right by the desk. I normally use the wireless though, which has really good signal in the room and no problems with the connection/speed etc.
name: C18

body: Decent holiday storage overhead lockers above three wardrobes. Gets good daylight but not too much so it doesn't get too hot in summer. Door makes an annoying scraping sound each time you open and close it.
name: D13

body: Very nice room, plenty of space to have mates round if you spin the bed around against the wall and move the desk under the window. Lovely views out the window over the gardens. The trek up to the third floor isn't as bad as it first seems, its just a bit of effort when moving in and out with all your bags.
name: B17

body: Long shaped room. Holiday storage yes. Blue coloured walls. Kitchen is only a few feet away which is very very convenient ;) Room is located bang on the centre of the college which is a plus... but it can get a little noisy. Fantastic wardrobe space!
name: J1

body:
Nice big room, plenty of holiday storage. No immediate neighbours as surrounded by function rooms/kitchen which is very convenient. Literally the closest room to the porters' lodge. Window looks out over front court, with access to the first floor walkway.

***Chronic problem of a dripping ceiling light during heavy rain.***
name: J4

body:
- View onto the trees at the back
- Small holiday storage
- 'L' shaped
- Reasonable daylight on one half of room
- Not facing sun
- Other half has little/no daylight
name: E17

body: Right next to the kitchen. Probably one of the smaller of the Standard plus rooms, but still a pretty decent size.
name: L1

body:
- Daylight: Average
 - Pretty big compared to some other rooms
 - Backs onto walkway

Pretty nice room overall (even if the wardrobe is tiny)
name: E7

body:
Best room in the world! Pretty large for a standard (but weird trapezium shape), has an ajoined balcony that's as large as the room (summer BBQ?). The other doors on the balcony goes to the fellow suite's living room and kitchen, and they usually never come out. So the balcony is all yours. 1 Locker overhead storage space above wardrobe that fits a large suitcase comfortably. Standard kitchen upstairs. Brilliant view to the garden but is on the shady side. Very quiet if the neighbours behave... Oh yeah there is full tiling on the corridor wall that lead to J12! TILES! Need I say more? ;)

----------

The light is pretty awful. Otherwise a very nice room.
name: J11

body:
Plenty of holiday storage in the roof.

No sink in rooms, toilet in one room and sink/shower in another room.

Really nice view of the gardens with plenty of natural light, shared balcony with M13.

Kitchen on the same floor which is convienient.

On the top floor so not ideal for moving in and out, but that's pretty much the only downside to this room.
name: M14

body:
Good size room, right opposite the library.

Although, no lockable cupboard.
name: G9

body: The stairs keep you fit but your not too far from anywhere. Occasionally people have parties in j8 till quite late which you can hear. Its has a balcony shared with j14 and you get good views of the garden. Kitchen is on same floor and it has a sky light you can open so its pretty hard to set off the fire alarm by accident.
name: J15

body: Horrid room, really noisy when people walk back and forth and gossip outside your room.. the radiator rarely works. The organ scholar is constantly playing various instruments in the room below.. very noisy!
name: F10

body: Medium-sized with balcony (shared with H14) overlooking the garden.
name: H13

body:
Decent sized room. No garden view, but high enough to look over the college, into some trees. Very light (nearly South-facing), with a balcony shared with a room on B-staircase. Lapwing occasionally decides to work, though I have only succeeded in using it once so should not be relied upon. Decent sized wardrobe, working and warm radiator, easy access for network socket, nice armchair included.

The only problem is the lack of overhead storage meaning that you have to take everything home or leave it in the trunk room.
name: C15

body: Garden facing balcony, but the window let's in a big draft. Even when the window is fully closed on really windy nights, I can sometimes feel the wind when I'm in bed. But a lot of cupboard storage space and right in the centre of college, opposite the porter's lodge and the library. Altogether, a  nice room.
name: I3

body: This is a great room, it is quite large with a very nice garden view, and handy for the kitchen. The main issue is all the stairs, but the shower is also very poor (low pressure, temperature changes).
name: D20

body: There is no description for this room, why not consider adding one?
name: G1

body:
With sweeping views over the University library and the courtyard this is one of the perfect rooms for people who enjoy the sight of bricks. Unfortunately their is no garden view but you can just about see one or two trees in the opposite car park.

There is no holiday storage at all, which is a bit of a pain.
name: P12

body:
This room is big for a standard plus and has a nice en suite. Negative point - it is very dark and gets little daylight.

The room got refitted with a new bathroom (in a sly attempt by College to try and make it seem like a good room despite the utter darkness which prevails all day every day). It's a very nice bathroom though. If you're a heated-towel-rail loving vampire (like me!) then you'll love the room. It's also really big!
name: C6

body: Very plesant room except for lack of garden-facing balcony.
name: I1

body: The room has a good view over the main court yard, over looking the chapel and Porter's Lodge, and get's good light during most of the day (much better than garden facing rooms) which can make the room really warm. Bathroom facilities are shared. There is no holiday storage.
name: J9

body:
- No holiday storage
- North-facing, so light levels are variable
- Shared shower sometimes has hot and cold phases

NB There are quite a lot of stairs to walk up and down
name: E20

body: Nice and convenient room just next to the kitchen.
name: I2

body: Big 3 doors wardrobe.
name: S1

body:
- Warm
 - Decent Lapwing signal
 - Phone signal dodgy

_______________________

Staying here 2012-2013. Eduroam (we no longer use Lapwing) signal is great, always works and is picked up by all my devices. Phone signal is also great. The room is warm, and very spacious. Also very close to both the bar, restaurant, and plodge, but is still far enough from the bar that it isn't too noisy. Only downside is the lack of proper balcony, but that's what comes with first floor rooms.
name: M1

body: Smaller than many 'Best' rooms and slightly peculiarly shaped, provocative inscription left on the desk presumbably by some rugby lad years ago, found a pair of shorts behind one of the drawers....
name: F9

body:
Bit of an odd room because it's on the corner of college. This means it's quite big for a standard, it's got two balconies (although one is smaller and just goes to the fire exit) and it's a funny shape (corner-like, in fact). It's got a bigger wardrobe than other rooms I've been in, and a big overhead locker on top. The window has a view over the Adam's road gardens. The big window and two balcony doors means you get a lot of light, which is nice.

It is quiet, which can be a good thing when you are trying to work.
name: S8

body: Fairly standard, everything works, room layouts not brilliant - there'll be better rooms knocking around but this one isn't bad at all.
name: C11

body:
Relatively quiet with good garden view. Facilities in working order. Close to college amenities, useful lift. Some ladybird issues. Suffers the usual common faults of College rooms.

Staircase Facilities
-------------------------

Excessively leisurely lift invaluable for moving in and out. Spatially proximate to bar. Kitchen on floor above is small - the door does not open fully. It contains a combi-wave and normal microwave - both in working order, capacious cupboard-space. Fridge with a tiny freezer shelf. Two electric hobs.

Construction
----------------
6 walls. Dual windows open and close, inadequate sealing, with a panoramic view of the College Garden. Fire escape, or what could generously be described as a balcony, connects to adjacent room on L staircase. Shares other wall with a K staircase flat.

Door is sub-par: poor fitting gives an uneven top and bottom edge; small gash on exterior of door artisanly repaired with sticky-back plastic; interior 'Please Lock Me' label well-worn; no clothes hook. The door's general design is flawed in that there is a 5cm chasm between the floor and the bottom of the door that prevents the use of a standard door wedge and accommodates a substantial burst of light should the hall light be left on at night - though this can be corrected by judicious placing of the bed.

Carpet is to good approximation horizontal, contains one cm-sized lump of solder (included).

Wall paint condition: generally good, one or two chips, very few scuffs; broadly even application.

Noise
-------

Noise: Quieter than average most of the time.

Floor creakiness: About average.

Adjacent (anisotropic weighting) room floor creakiness: Quieter than average.

Bathroom Facilities
-------------------------
Suffer from drawbacks common to all College rooms: binary shower temperature; bathroom mirror fitted defiantly on wall perpendicular to and away from sink; and the underpowered flush mechanism leaves something to be desired. The bathroom now has a miniature plastic bin. Sink and shower drain well.

Furniture and Fittings
----------------------------
Standard.

Mirror is missing top right screw cap, otherwise reflects well.

Power: there are four standard plug sockets, 2 near the desk and 2 on the opposite side of the room near your bed - last PAT in 2002. Radiator provides sufficient heating.

5 standard depth non-equidistant shelves. Two solid chairs, ample back support. Modern kettle, with holster, and a below average volume of limescale. Solid desk.

The bed is of sturdy construction and comfort; it is a relatively quiet bed.

Hanging rail lacks metal clips to secure hangars and directly above bed, so of limited use.

The noticeboard is in good condition and has a structural surplus of 6 drawing pins.

Wardrobe locking magnets are somewhat overpowered. Depthwise hanging could be more generous.

Vacation Storage
-----------------------
Contains standard vacation storage in overhead locker. However, this also suffers from a fundamental design flaw: its vertical hinging means that to operate you must either risk breaking your possessions, have a school window opening pole, or risk loss of conciousness. Having a horizontal hinging system would also prevent a padlock with an unfortunate moment of inertia annoying conference guests every time they open the wardrobe.

Lighting
----------
West-facing so no overheating. Natural desk light is OK. Main light is very dim. Desk lights are energy-saving and bright.
name: K7

body: Nice view of the garden and has a small shared balcony. The radiator is behind the desk (which you can't move because of the position of the internet connection plug), which isn't good for heating the room or drying clothes, but it still stays relatively warm.
name: H11

body: D14 is a good sized room with a nice layout. It gets plenty of sunlight which means the room is always warm but this can be a bit of a pain as you have to shut the curtains when working to keep the sun off your computer screen. Hanging space is a bit limited but there is still enough and there is vacation storage space. Shares a balcony with E11 though the view from the balcony is rubbish unless you like looking out onto a roof. I kept this same room from last year and would say its good points make the flaws bearable.
name: D14

body:
Pretty standard for a standard plus room.  

 - Nice size
 - Nice View
 - Bit dark
 - Good triple wardrobe
 - Big Desk
name: D4

body: Nice room, no natural light, really noisy cause people are always in and out of the kitchen, lots of spiders from being next to the gardens.. it's CRAP!!!!
name: F1

body: It's a nice room. If you leave the window open, bits of the tree come in. This also sometimes happens in room 11.
name: Room 12

body:
This is a good sized ensuite room. It has a fair amount of holiday storage and a wardrobe. The room is very quiet, since it is on the opposite side of the college to the bar etc. It has a bit of a dismal view (of a roof) but the wondows open out onto the end of the second floor walkway, so people don't ever really walk past.

The network connection is right behind the desk.
name: F14

body:
I got very fond of this room but it is absolutely tiny - it's smaller than a Value room but you are forced to pay for a Standard room. (Unless, like me, you refuse to pay and persuade the bursar to give you a discount).

Various problems include:
- lack of space, meaning that there is no room for a bedside table

- the wall between this room and the flat next door is only one sheet of hardboard, and you can therefore hear everything said next door.

- the bathroom isn't split between shower/toilet

- there's a lack of plug sockets

- it's right above the J8 function room, so that can get a bit noisy

Other than that, it's right across the court from the plodge and it does provide an air of cosiness!
name: J10

body: Huge Room, lots of floorspace. Next to kitchen. 2 bathrooms and a toilet shared between 3 rooms on this floor, so there is always one free.
name: Room 5

body:
Pretty big room; I don't think I've been in another Standard Plus room that's any bigger, with lots of wall space for your posters, etc. The bathroom is also reasonably spacious. Everything seems to be logically placed, such as the ethernet port being next to the desk and so on. I've never been able to get a decent wifi signal really, though I haven't spent that much time trying - there may be certain areas of the room where you can get signal since it is so close to the cafe. Walk down two flights of stairs and you're outside the bar, and the fact that it is two floors down means that you don't get much of the noise from it either. It also has a medium sized lockable cupboard above the wardrobe for vacation storage which as I found last vacation, is larger than you think, I only describe it as medium because I've seen larger ones in some rooms.

I guess the only downside is the fact that it doesn't really have a balcony, as it backs out onto the walkway around college, but some people may prefer that.

Get it if you want a large room that is conveniently located very close to the bar, cafe, canteen, hall - basically the main "social hotspots" of college.
Don't get it if you would prefer a quieter location, as this is what I would describe as the busier side of college.
name: N5

body:
Good
----
+ Pretty large room
+ Two desks
+ Sink in the room
+ Bath/shower directly opposite
+ Two toilets on this floor
+ Kitchen directly opposite

Bad
---
- Rather expensive for what it is
- No lockable storage
- Cold in winter, even with both radiators on
- Rather noisy from the kitchen
- Not much fridge/freezer space
- Desks by the window, too much direct sunlight
- Not much natural light in the rest of the room (lights on most of the time)
- Whole house feels a bit old/run-down (furniture a bit aged, walls in need of repainting)
name: Room 11

body:
The room has its own (not shared) balcony on college side as it is at the end of college. It has no lockable cupboard, and the door rattles when it is windy.

The kitchen above is normally quiet as the staricase is the smallest in college.
name: S9

body:
Balcony shared with P13.

Pros :

- Good view
- Kitchen on same floor
- Quiet and peaceful and out of the way
- Close to bar, canteen and side exit door to path to river

Cons :

- Top floor so lots of climbing to do
- Small Size
- No vacation storage

Other notes : Late afternoon sun, can be in eyes at times and room isnt warmed up/illuminated by sun as much as I'd like.
name: P14

body: Basement room at the end of college. The room can be a little dark/cold due to the tree outside the window.
name: A1

body: Total lack of sunlight, horrible court facing view. Skanky bath. But generally alright.
name: N4

body:
Sure, you have to climb a lot of stairs to get to it, and sure, you have to share a bathroom with two other people and granted, there's no place to put your stuff over the holidays and O.K. its a mite smaller than the non-value rooms, but appart from all that R13 is one of the finest rooms in college.

Currently around £600 less per year than a standard room, R13 is almost as big as a standard and far bigger than many of the value rooms in the houses. It also has an interesting view onto high court where, if you're lucky, of a morning you can see the dupty warden exiting his personal chambers for a stroll. On top of this, there's more than enough light in the room to keep you from getting seasonal affective disorder (SAD).

It also has roof access, which you're not allowed to use, of course, but if you did would possibly provide a sterling view onto the vista of central cambridge, including the tips of Kings college chapel, the law faculty, the UL and burrels walk. Oh, R13, how could I ask for anything more?
name: R13

body: A lovely little number. A pretty spacious ensuite, and although forward facing you actually get a view of some trees and a bit of Herschel Road. It's up at a quiet end of college too, which may be worth considering, although it is slightly further away from the bar (but if you really wanted a pint you'd run). Overhead storage space above wardrobe and a fantastic new kettle with billions of exciting features such as boil, evaporate and bubble. Although it's on a walkway, it's relatively quiet as the only people that walk past are those going to A staircase (or occassionally a lone maintenance man with a spanner).
name: B7

body: Has an excellent name
name: K9

body: Faces the rugby pitch, reasonable daylight, no sink. Narrow balcony shared with next-door. Pretty unremarkable room generally.
name: B18

body:
Average Standard Plus Room, close to the library and plodge. No direct connection to the ground level (Auditorium) - bit annoying.
Bathtub looks quite old... otherwise a decent room.
name: H5

body:
Balcony Shared with M10 but off walkway so noone walks past
Balcony overlooks the smoking area which means it can be quite loud but also useful to work out who is around college.
No holiday storage
name: L12

body: Refurbished but small standard plus.
name: Q9

body:
Standard Ensuite college room with the usual features. The walls have been painted a mild yellow which helps brighten up the room. Being a garden facing room on Herschel court, you get little sunlight, but this comes in handy during easter term when the other rooms get quite hot. Everything in's pretty good condition (a few scratches on the windows might annoy a few people though) and the mattress has been replaced. Keep in mind it's a two floor trip to the nearest kitchen (although during Michaelmas/Lent putting things by the window keeps some stuff chilled).

Being a bit away from the centre of college, it's a little quieter but you still get the usual noise from bops, other rooms, creaky floorboards etc...
name: C9

body:
B8 is a pretty awesome room. Hallway with a double wardrobe and storage space for the holidays, and a bit bigger in all than most Standard Plus rooms. It's really quiet, although there are a few pianists nearby. It gets a bit dingy in the winter, but you can sleep without morning sun coming into the room. Shares the long balcony with all of the court's staircases. You're going to have to walk two staircases to get to a kitchen, but that's definitely better than being on the top floor.

asd x
name: B8

body:
Fairly spacious room because its quite square. Gets lots of sunlight in the morning; wakes you up in time for lectures; annoying if you want a lie in. Has a nice little balcony with a great view of the front court although people can see in to your room from some of the teaching rooms opposite.

Gets a lot noise from front court after formals/cindies nights etc and for some reason the sound of people walking/running across the walkway on the floor below resonates quite loudly into the room. The cupboard is also a little small and high up and there is no holiday storage. Another thing is that quite a lot of spiders make their way into the room during winter and there is always a spider web across the balcony door meaning you get a faceful of spiderweb everytime you step outside.

All in all a nicely laid out room with lots a light but also gets a lot of noise.
name: H9

body:
There's a huge draft from the door- you can mitigate it mostly by leaning a heavy book against it.
What's kinda annoying is that there's only one plug socket near the desk (unlike L13)-- you can either have light or have your laptop on charge, not both :(
name: L14

body: Spacious room. Next door to the kitchen but the kitchen door makes a loud clicking noise when closed. Large wardrobe with a large storage cupboard above. In basement from Herschel Court but a few steps up from ground level from the garden side. A bit low on natural light. Can get cold in cold weather due to the draught from the outside door down the corridor but this can be solved by closing the room's inside door. Network socket and desk on opposite wall to the pin board.Two double electrical sockets (one next to desk and network socket) and a single one near the bed. No shelf in the bathroom. Nice view of the trees and the squirrels can come pretty close to the window too.
name: D1

body:
This room is great. It is a really good size and shape, so you can move your furniture around heaps of times.

It is on the third floor, which means a fair few steps to climb when you're bringing your luggage up. But it is manageable, and fortunately not at the very, very top. And the extremely useful storage space it has above the wardrobe definitely makes up for the stairs!

It is also such a conveniently placed room college-wise - in the middle of centre court and opposite the library. You will also have a shared balcony with a lovely view and space to chill.

Definitely one of the best standard rooms in college.
name: H10

body: Good skylight.
name: Room 13

body:
Decent sized room, if you put the desk under the window and the bed against the wall it increases the amount of floor space you have dramatically.

Lovely view but the windows can let the cold in if the wind is coming from the wrong direction.

In the evenings it can get a little dark as there aren't really enough lights.
name: O10

body: Normal sized room, no overhead locker :-( Reasonable amount of light. Balcony is shared with an office so, really, it's all yours.
name: S7

body:
Bad points: North-facing, so gets no direct sunlight. Can feel small if you do something daft like put the wardrobe in front of the window (how it was when I found it).
Good points: You can rearrange the room to make it look massive, if you bring power-extension-cables, but there isn't much spare space. You don't have to go upstairs/downstairs to get to the bathroom. The squirrels in the tree opposite are also a good source of procrastination. There's not too much noise from elsewhere in the house (kitchen & hall). The ceiling has not fallen in yet.
name: Room 10

body: Nice room, on the smaller side but makes up for it in being on the same floor as the kitchen, little noise, great view of the gardens. 3 door-wardrobe although no holiday storage space
name: P13

body:
A staircase is on Herschel Court.
Kitchens in the Basement and on the 4th Floor.
name: Staircase A

body:
Flats are designed for 3 people. They consist of 3 bedrooms and a bathroom on ground level, and downstairs there is a living area and kitchen for the flat. Again, if you wish to choose a flat, all three people must be together in the room ballot. Flats tend to be taken very early on in the ballot, so be realistic about your chances of getting a flat.

body: There is no description for this house, why not consider adding one?
name: 6 Adams

body:
What to do:

1. Decide who, if anyone, you would like to ballot with.  Write your name(s) on a piece of paper fold it up and put it in the appropriate box in the Plodge by 1pm Saturday 16th Feb. **Note that it is important to ballot even if you are not balloting in a group. Failure to ballot results in you being at the very bottom of the choosing order and you may not get a room that suits you.**

2. If you want to, come to the JCR for the draw at 7pm on Sunday 17th Feb.  The order of the draw will be the order in which you choose your rooms. **You do not have to choose rooms in the exact same place as those you balloted with, you just choose the room you’re getting at the same time as them.**  This order gets reversed for choosing in your second year.  Don’t worry if you cannot make the actual draw, although most people usually like to be there - the results along with the times you are expected to choose at will be posted the next day in the JCR.

3. Check the ballot list in the JCR - note the time for choosing allocated to you. Look at the college plans on the JCR notice boards and get an idea of what room you would like to pick.

4. Turn up to choose your room on Wednesday 27th February.  Please arrive at least 5 minutes before the time printed on the lists in the JCR to see which rooms are still available.

Groups
------

Balloting in a group ensures that you all get to choose at a similar point in the ballot - so you can choose a room near your friends.  Groups must be limited to a maximum of 5. If you want to ballot in a group, put all the names on one piece of paper and **ensure that every member of the group has signed it before** placing it in the ballot box. You will be placed in the order that your names appear on the piece of paper.

You may also wish to come and see some of the 2nd year choosing at 7pm on Monday 25th Feb to get an idea of how everything works.

Sets and Flats
--------------

All individuals who wish to choose a set or flat must ballot together, i.e. sets or flats can only be filled by people who are directly next to each other in the ballot. This means that an individual cannot choose one room in a flat or set and then hold it for other individuals further down the ballot. 

Round 2
-------

The second round is designed to allow individuals to fill any unfilled flats and sets that were not filled by groups in the first round.  It also allows people to swap into fresher rooms. However, there must be a convincing reason for that change and the fresher room must be the same price or more expensive, so as to prevent the fresher pool becoming too expensive.  All swaps are at the Vice President’s discretion.

What Rooms Are Available?
-------------------------

Within the main college building there approximately 300 rooms, ranging in price, en suite/shared, view etc. This also includes a small number of sets (house two) and flats (house three). These sets and flats, however, often go early on in the ballot.

The college owns houses on Adams Road and Sylvester Road; approximately 80 rooms will be available to undergraduates.

Plans, full room lists, predicted rents and facilities information will be available on the notice boards in the JCR from Saturday 9th Feb.

Living Out
----------

Nobody has to live out of college accommodation, but you may do so if you wish. However, you will not receive a living out allowance as the choice is voluntary. If you decide to live out, you should contact the University Accommodation Service at Kellet Lodge, Tennis Court Road, or visit http://www.accommodation.cam.ac.uk/, who should be able to help you find appropriate accommodation. If you are going to live out, inform me and do not enter the room ballot.  If you are considering living out, please note:

- Those who opt to live out at the ballot stage cannot opt back in and expect to be accommodated.  Only after the freshers have been allocated rooms in the first week in September will it be clear whether there are rooms available.

- If a student takes part in the ballot and subsequently opts to live out, he or she will have permanently deprived him/herself of the room allocated; if he or she subsequently opts back in, the room allocation is likely to take place at the earliest only after the freshers have been allocated rooms in the first week in September.

- A student who opts to live out prior to the end of Easter Term (for 12/13 this is Friday 14 June 2013) will have no obligation for Residence Charge in the Michaelmas term, even if his or her decision results in a room being left empty.

- A student who opts to live out after the end of Easter Term will be required to pay a term’s Residence Charge for the room he or she had been allocated if his or her decision results in an undergraduate room being left vacant.

- Students who decide to live out after the start of the academic year will always be required to give one full-term’s notice, otherwise a term’s Residence Charge in lieu of notice will be chargeable (for example: notice given on or before the first day of the Michaelmas term will not be liable for the Lent term’s Residence Charge; however, notice given after the first day of the Michaelmas term remainders responsible for the Lent term’s Residence Charge).  Notice must be given in writing and sent to the Finance Bursar

What Then?
----------

After the end of Easter Term all correspondence and decisions regarding undergraduate room allocations will be handled by Karen Kempton (kak24) the College Accommodation Officer.  Only under exceptional circumstances will student initiated room swaps be permitted after the end of Easter Term each year.

**When considering your choice, try to have a variety of rooms in mind. Once you know your position in the ballot, be realistic about your possible choices.  Look at the plans, go and look at rooms if you wish (people generally don't mind), and please turn up to choose on time.**

**Please note that if anyone does not submit their name before the allotted time they will not be included in the ballot. They will be placed at the bottom of the appropriate list, post-ballot.**

**Above all, don't worry about it!  Please contact me with any doubts, queries or problems.**

Mary Hughes

RCSA Vice President 2012/13
name: Current First Years

body:

1. Write your name(s) on a piece of paper and put it in the appropriate ballot box in the Plodge by 1pm on Saturday 16th Feb.

2. Turn up for the ballot on Sunday 17th Feb (7pm JCR). The order of the draw will be the order of choosing.

3. Check the JCR from Monday 18th Feb for your choosing time.

4. Turn up to choose on Wednesday 27th Feb at least 5 minutes early to see which rooms are still available.

Groups:

They are Best rooms, so if the bottom three in the ballot don’t want them I will make them available to the first 3 people who do in the 3rd year ballot (more info on that when the choosing order is set!)

name: Current Third Years

body:
What to do:

1. Check the JCR for the revised order of last year's choosing (JCR notice boards from Saturday 9th Feb)
2. If you want to form a new group with no more than 5 people, please notify me by email 
(meh65) by 1pm Saturday 16th Feb. The position of the new group will be determined by the average position of its members. If you want to remain in the same group as last year, please also email me with your names so I can ensure a newly formed group won’t separate your group.
3.  Check the revised ballot order from Sunday 17th Feb for your choosing time

other, will therefore have to re-ballot. The only exception to this rule is where two individuals from
